questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, G2P1, comes to the emergency department in active labor. She has not received prenatal care during this pregnancy. A 3500g boy is delivered by an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows low-set ears, micrognathia and clenched fingers. Abdominal examination shows a midline non-reducible mass covered by a whitish membrane. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's abdominal findings?

choices.text: Failure of lateral body fold fusion

questions.solution:
This newborn infant boy has a midline non-reducible mass covered in a whitish membrane, which is consistent with omphalocele. Omphalocele is often associated with other anomalies, including chromosomal (e.g. trisomies 13 and 18), syndromic (e.g. Beckwith-Wiedemann) and other structural anomalies (e.g., cardiac, genitourinary, neural tube). This patient has low set ears, micrognathia and clenched fingers, and therefore most likely has Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18).  

Both gastroschisis and omphalocele are ventral abdominal wall defects, and they can often be confused with each other. However, these are distinct clinical entities, with different presentations, embryologic causes, and outcomes. During embryological development, the four body folds (rostral, caudal, and two lateral folds) fuse to form a normal abdominal wall. Omphalocele occurs when lateral folds fail to migrate and fuse at the umbilical ring. This failure causes the abdominal contents to remain persistently herniated into the umbilicus instead of returning to the abdominal cavity during the 10th week of embryological development. The abdominal contents are midline as they protrude through the umbilicus, and are covered with peritoneum.   

Gastroschisis occurs when the abdominal wall fails to close normally, and it is believed to be due to disrupted blood flow to the developing abdominal wall. The intestines are not covered with peritoneum and protrude typically to the right of the umbilicus. This condition is usually an isolated defect, with approximately 10% having an associated anomaly.
 


Both defects can be detected early in pregnancy via ultrasound, and an elevated maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) can also be seen (higher in gastroschisis than omphalocele). Both can be treated with surgical repair after birth. The overall survival with gastroschisis is over 90%, while survival in omphalocele is lower mainly due to associated anomalies.  

Option Analysis

❌ Persistence of the vitelline duct :
Incorrect: Persistence of the vitelline duct (omphalomesenteric) is the cause of Meckel diverticulum. The vitelline duct joins the yolk sac to the midgut lumen of the developing fetus. It may contain ectopic acid-secreting gastric mucosa and/or pancreatic tissue and can present with pain, hematochezia (bloody feces), intussusception, and/or volvulus. It does not present with a sack protruding through the abdominal wall. 
❌ Failure of urachus involution :
Incorrect: The urachus is a duct that connects the fetal bladder and the umbilicus. Failure of urachus to involute can cause a patent urachus, urachal cyst, or vesicoureteral diverticulum. In the case of a patent urachus, the patient would have urine coming out of the umbilicus. A urachal cyst would present with a painful mass below the umbilicus. 
✅ Failure of lateral body fold fusion :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Failure of umbilical ring closure :
Incorrect: Improper closure of the umbilical ring after reduction of the intestines during embryological development results in an umbilical hernia. The hernia is usually reducible, asymptomatic, and resolves in the first few years of life. In contrast to omphalocele, in which the body folds fail to fuse, in umbilical hernias, the body folds develop properly. The physiologic midgut herniation persists and results in a simple hernia that is covered by the skin. 
❌ Failure of gut rotation  :
Incorrect: Failure of the gut to rotate is the cause of intestinal malrotation. During 4th-8th week of embryonic development, there is physiologic extrusion and reduction of the gut through the umbilical ring. The gut performs 270°-degree rotation around the axis of the superior mesenteric artery. The abnormal position of the gut is termed malrotation. It does not cause a protrusion through the abdominal wall.

questions.text: A 2-day-old infant girl is observed to have several episodes of bilious vomiting while in the nursery. The vomiting occurs shortly after feeding. She was born full-term to a 38-year-old, gravida 2 para 2, female via vaginal delivery. The pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. The patient’s vitals are notable for hypotension and tachycardia. Examination of the skull reveals sunken anterior and posterior fontanelles. The patient is also observed to have upslanted palpebral fissure and prominent epicanthal folds. A single transverse palmar crease is noted on the bilateral hands. The patient has a scaphoid abdomen. Digital rectal examination reveals normal rectal tone and no expulsion of gas or stool. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Ischemia and reabsorption of the jejunum
Failure of the duodenum to recanalize
Impaired neural crest cell migration into the intestinal walls
Abnormal rotation of the small intestines

questions.solution:
This patient has duodenal atresia, a condition associated with trisomy 21. During embryological development, the primitive gut tube undergoes a solid stage where proliferating cells fill it up. Normally, the gut subsequently undergoes recanalization, and the lumen re-forms. If recanalization fails in the region giving rise to the duodenum, the result is duodenal atresia.  

A similar condition is jejunal/ileal atresia, which occurs when ischemia causes necrosis and reabsorption of portions of the gut tube. The condition is associated with cystic fibrosis.  

Both conditions result in a blind pouch and intestinal obstruction. In utero, these conditions cause polyhydramnios. After birth, these conditions cause difficulty feeding and vomiting. The vomitus can be non-bilious or bilious depending on whether the obstruction is proximal/distal to the major duodenal papilla, respectively. Additionally, patients with duodenal atresia can develop biliary atresia and annular pancreas because the region of the embryonic gut giving rise to the duodenum also gives rise to the pancreas and hepatobiliary tree.    
Both conditions are diagnosed by radiography. Duodenal atresia causes the “double-bubble sign”, where both the duodenum and nearby stomach are filled with air. Jejunal atresia causes the “triple-bubble sign,” where the jejunum is also dilated.
 

This abdominal radiograph shows the classic “double bubble” sign with a gas-filled distended stomach and duodenum and an absence of distal gas
Reproduced from: Wikipedia

Option Analysis

❌ Ischemia and reabsorption of the jejunum :
Incorrect: This answer describes the underlying cause of jejunal atresia, which is associated with cystic fibrosis. In contrast, this patient’s physical exam findings of upslanted palpebral fissures, prominent epicanthal folds, and single transverse palmar creases are consistent with trisomy 21. Patients with trisomy 21 are at increased risk of developing duodenal atresia. 
✅ Failure of the duodenum to recanalize :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  Hypertrophy of the pyloric sphincter :
Incorrect: This answer describes hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. However, the condition would cause non-bilious vomiting, since the pyloric sphincter is before the duodenal papilla, the location of bile secretion.  
❌ Impaired neural crest cell migration into the intestinal walls :
Incorrect: This answer describes Hirschsprung disease. Patients with trisomy 21 are at increased risk of developing the condition, and Hirschsprung disease can cause bilious vomiting. However, it would also cause a distended abdomen, since stool cannot be eliminated, as opposed to a scaphoid abdomen. Additionally, neonates with Hirschsprung disease typically have a positive squirt sign (expulsion of stool on digital rectal examination), as well as increased rectal tone, neither of which are seen in this patient. 
❌ Abnormal rotation of the small intestines :
Incorrect: Malrotation of the intestines can lead to a midgut volvulus. It can cause intestinal obstruction, vomiting, and a distended abdomen. However, many of this patient’s physical examination findings (e.g., prominent epicanthal folds, single transverse palmar crease) are consistent with trisomy 21, which predisposes patients to developing duodenal atresia.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man comes to the clinic due for a follow-up after hospitalization. He was hospitalized two weeks ago for pneumonia and was treated with ampicillin-sulbactam. Medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus and aortic stenosis. Further medical history reveals 2 prior hospitalizations in the past year for pneumonia. The patient reports difficulty swallowing and regurgitation of undigested food particles. A barium esophagram is performed and shown below:  


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following areas is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has dysphagia, regurgitation and recurrent episodes of pneumonia. Along with the barium swallow test results, the most likely diagnosis is a Zenker diverticulum.   

Zenker diverticulum is an outpouching of the mucosa and submucosa through the Killian triangle (also called the Killian dehiscence), an area in the posterior wall of the pharynx between the cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus (the 2 parts of the inferior constrictors). The pathogenesis of Zenker diverticulum is not entirely clear, but it is thought to be associated with altered function of the upper esophageal sphincter, esophageal dysmotility, or esophageal shortening. This dysfunction leads to impaired bolus passage and increased intraluminal pressure. As a result, the mucosa and submucosa emerge through a natural area of weakness, the Killian's triangle. In contrast to a Meckel diverticulum, a Zenker diverticulum is a false diverticula which contains only mucosa and submucosa. Patients typically present with complaints of dysphagia, regurgitation, halitosis (bad breath), and occasionally an observed neck mass. Possible complications include aspiration pneumonia, ulceration and bleeding (due to retained oral medications), fistula formation, and vocal cord paralysis (pressure buildup from retained food). Squamous cell carcinoma in the diverticulum is a rare complication.  

 



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: This area is the junction between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors muscles. It is not involved in the pathogenesis of Zenker's diverticulum.      
❌ B:
Incorrect: This area is the junction between the middle and inferior pharyngeal constrictors muscles. It is not involved in the pathogenesis of Zenker's diverticulum.  
❌ C:
Incorrect: This is the thyropharyngeus part muscle, the upper part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictors muscle. However, Zenker's diverticulum occurs below this muscle.  
✅ D:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ E:
Incorrect: This is the cricopharyngeus muscle, the lower part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle. However, Zenker's diverticulum occurs above this muscle.  
❌ F:
Incorrect: This is the junction between the circular and longitudinal fibers of the esophagus. This area is not involved in Zenker's diverticulum formation.  
❌ G:
Incorrect: This is the junction between the left and right longitudinal fibers of the esophagus. This area is not involved in Zenker's diverticulum formation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute epigastric pain, dark stools, and lightheadedness. The patient reports abdominal pain over the past several weeks, but today the pain acutely worsened after eating breakfast. She reports passing out in the bathroom after passing a large volume of dark stool. Medical history includes hypertension and chronic gastroesophageal reflux. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 111/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 104/62 mmHg. Physical examination shows tenderness on palpation of the epigastrium. The patient undergoes emergent upper endoscopy which reveals active bleeding just distal to the pylorus. Which of the following vascular structures is most likely implicated as a consequence of this patient’s disease process?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with melena, syncope, and acute on chronic abdominal pain with an endoscopy demonstrating bleeding just distal to the pylorus, concerning for a bleeding duodenal ulcer. Hemorrhage is the most common complication of peptic ulcer disease, and the most commonly implicated communicating artery in this anatomic region is the gastroduodenal artery, which runs just posterior to the duodenum.  

Bleeding is more likely to occur when ulcers penetrate the posterior surface of the stomach or duodenum. The most common gastric ulcers implicated in bleeding tend to affect the left gastric artery located on the lesser curvature of the stomach. Gastric ulcers may also erode into the splenic, short gastric, or gastroepiploic arteries depending on their anatomic location. Conversely, duodenal ulcers classically erode into the gastroduodenal artery.

Bleeding ulcers usually require treatment during endoscopy, including injection therapy, thermal coagulation, hemostatic clips, or a combination of treatments. Additionally, patients should be managed with the usual treatment of upper gastrointestinal bleeding, including proton pump inhibitor therapy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Gastroduodenal artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Left gastric artery:
Incorrect: The left gastric artery runs along the lesser curvature of the stomach and is the most commonly implicated artery in gastric ulcers. This patient’s bleeding is post-pyloric.  
❌ Right gastroepiploic artery  :
Incorrect: The right gastroepiploic artery runs along the medial border of the greater curvature of the stomach and is more commonly implicated in gastric ulcers. However, this is an uncommon site for gastric ulcers to form.   
❌ Splenic artery:
Incorrect: The splenic artery arises from the celiac trunk and runs along the posterior border of the stomach. Ulcers that arise on the posterior border of the stomach may erode into this artery, causing bleeding. However, this patient’s bleeding is post-pyloric.  
❌ Left gastroepiploic artery:
Incorrect: The left gastroepiploic artery runs along the lateral border of the greater curvature of the stomach and is more commonly implicated in gastric ulcers. However, this is an uncommon site for gastric ulcers to form. Moreover, this patient’s bleeding is post-pyloric.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old man is hospitalized for recurrent pneumonia. This is the patient’s fourth hospitalization for pneumonia in the past six months, and bronchial lavage cultures have consistently grown Bacteroides sp susceptible to ampicillin-sulbactam. The patient undergoes a barium swallow study as demonstrated below during his hospitalization. Which of the following correctly identifies the anatomic location of this patient’s clinical condition?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

choices.text: Junction between the cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus
Junction between the middle and inferior pharyngeal constrictors muscles
Junction between the upper part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictors
Junction between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors
Junction between the circular and longitudinal fibers of the esophagus

questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent aspiration pneumonia, as evidenced by culture data growing oral flora. This patient's barium swallow study demonstrates an outpouching of the cervical esophagus, most consistent with a Zenker diverticulum.  

Zenker diverticulum refers to an outpouching of the esophageal mucosa and submucosa through Killian’s triangle (also called Killian’s dehiscence), an area in the posterior wall of the pharynx between the cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus (the two parts of the inferior constrictors). The pathogenesis of Zenker’s diverticulum is thought to be due to altered function of the upper esophageal sphincter (cricopharyngeus), esophageal dysmotility, and esophageal shortening. Dysfunction of these muscle groups results in impaired bolus passage, increased intraluminal pressure, and subsequent protrusion of mucosa and submucosa through Killian's triangle.  

Clinical features include recurrent dysphagia, halitosis, and cough. A common complication of this condition is recurrent aspiration pneumonia. If small, a Zenker diverticulum is treated conservatively; larger diverticula are traditionally treated with surgery to incise the cricopharyngeus muscle and resect the diverticulum.  

Option Analysis

✅ Junction between the cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Junction between the middle and inferior pharyngeal constrictors muscles:
Incorrect: The area between the middle and inferior pharyngeal constrictors muscles is not involved in a Zenker diverticulum's pathogenesis.
❌ Junction between the upper part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictors  :
Incorrect: The thyropharyngeus muscle refers to the upper part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictors muscle, which is not the site of formation of a Zenker diverticulum.
❌ Junction between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors:
Incorrect: The junction between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors is not involved in the pathogenesis of a Zenker diverticulum. 
❌ Junction between the circular and longitudinal fibers of the esophagus:
Incorrect: The junction between the circular and longitudinal fibers of the esophagus is not involved in Zenker diverticulum formation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after vomiting bright red blood. The patient was at home watching television when he suddenly felt nauseous and vomited. He denies any recent trauma. Past medical history is notable for chronic alcohol use disorder. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 105/60 mmHg, and pulse is 102/min. Physical exam shows scleral icterus and hepatosplenomegaly. An upper endoscopy is performed and reveals dilated veins in the distal esophagus that have ruptured. Shunting of blood and subsequent dilation of which of the following vessels is most likely to have caused this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Esophageal varices are dilated submucosal veins in the lower third of the esophagus. They are most often caused by portal hypertension, which may be secondary to liver cirrhosis brought about by hepatitis or chronic alcohol use. Portal hypertension leads to increased pressure within the small vessels that connect the portal circulation to the systemic circulation. Over time, these small systemic vessels dilate, and blood is shunted through these anastomoses, which have lower resistance than the liver circulation. In particular, dilation of the left gastric and azygos veins contributes to the development of esophageal varices.  

Patients with esophageal varices can have life-threatening hematemesis if the varices rupture. This complication may occur when eating hard food or during vomiting. In severe cases, patients may develop signs of circulatory insufficiency (e.g., hypotension, tachycardia).  

Treatment of actively bleeding esophageal varices is with endoscopic band ligation, which can also prevent recurrence of hemorrhage. In patients with esophageal varices with non-active bleeding, prophylaxis with a nonselective beta-blocker (e.g. propranolol) can be used; beta-blockers reduce the portal pressure, thereby reducing the risk of future bleeding.  



Option Analysis

❌ Short gastric vein:
 Incorrect: The short gastric vein is found on the greater curvature of the stomach. The vessel does not anastomose with the esophageal veins. Hence, even if shunting were to occur in the short gastric veins, it would not contribute to esophageal vein dilation or rupture.  
❌ Hemiazygos vein:
Incorrect: The hemiazygos vein drains blood from the posterior intercostal veins on the left side of the body. Although the vessel travels in close proximity to the esophagus, it does not contribute to the development of esophageal varices.  
❌ Paraumbilical vein:
Incorrect: Shunting and dilation of the paraumbilical veins can cause the caput medusae phenomenon, which is when tortuous and dilated veins are seen on the anterior abdomen. However, the paraumbilical veins do not contribute to the development of esophageal varices.  
✅ Left gastric vein:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Right gastric vein:
Incorrect: The right gastric vein is found along the lesser curvature of the stomach. However, it does not anastomose with veins in the esophagus. As a result, shunting of blood and dilation of the right gastric vein would not contribute to the development of esophageal varices.

A 45-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with abdominal pain. The patient reports worsening abdominal pain with associated vomiting occasionally after eating. The patient reports a 15-lb (6.8 kg) weight loss over the past 2 months. Vital signs demonstrate a temperature of  37°C (98.6 °F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/62 mmHg. Physical examination shows a thin man in no acute distress. There is tenderness to palpation in epigastrium as well as abdominal distension with ascites. 2+ peripheral edema of the lower extremities is noted. Auscultation reveals diminished breath sounds at the lung bases bilaterally. Laboratory results are notable for hypoalbuminemia. The patient undergoes endoscopy which shows prominent rugae in the gastric fundus. A gross pathologic specimen from a patient with the same condition is demonstrated below:  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia 

Histologic analysis of the gastric mucosa is most likely to demonstrate which of the following features?

choices.text: Rugal hypertrophy with parietal cell atrophy
Rugal hypertrophy with parietal cell hyperplasia
Metaplasia of the esophagus with columnar epithelium and goblet cells

questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette presents with progressively worsening abdominal pain, weight loss, and hypoalbuminemia. Additionally, the gross pathologic specimen reveals hypertrophied rugae, concerning for Ménétrier disease.

Ménétrier disease is an acquired pre-cancerous condition that results from hyperplasia of mucosal epithelial cells, although the specific pathologic mechanisms are poorly understood. Histologically, specimens will reveal loss of deep glandular components and parietal cell atrophy. Excess protein-containing mucus production results in hypoproteinemia and hypoalbuminemia. The resultant decrease in oncotic pressure can cause edema, pleural effusions, and ascites.    

Diagnosis is based on visualization of hypertrophic rugae during endoscopy and histologic evaluation. Patients with the disease are typically treated supportively with a high protein diet and serial endoscopic examinations to screen for the development of gastric carcinoma.   

Option Analysis

✅ Rugal hypertrophy with parietal cell atrophy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diffuse glandular atrophy and metaplasia:
Incorrect: Chronic gastritis is either due to autoimmune etiologies or H. pylori. In either case, histologic examination will demonstrate glandular atrophy and metaplasia. Gross examination may reveal loss of rugae as opposed to the hypertrophy seen in Ménétrier disease.   
❌ Rugal hypertrophy with parietal cell hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is a neuroendocrine gastrin-secreting tumor that results in hypertrophy due to the increased hyperplasia of parietal cells with subsequent acid production.   
❌ Mucin-filled cells with peripheral nuclei :
Incorrect: Diffuse gastric cancer presents with signet cells on histology. Gross specimens will demonstrate a stomach wall that is grossly thickened and leathery, termed linitis plastica.   
❌ Metaplasia of the esophagus with columnar epithelium and goblet cells:
Incorrect:  The gastroesophageal junction is implicated in Barrett esophagus. This metaplastic process occurs when stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by columnar epithelium and   goblet cells due to uncontrolled acid reflux.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with a 6 month history of worsening retrosternal burning pain and coughing after eating. The patient reports he has had similar symptoms over the past 10 years but states they have never been this severe. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. The patient's family history is significant for esophageal adenocarcinoma in his older brother. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy is performed, and an image of the gastroesophageal junction is shown below:  



Reproduced from: Wikipedia  

A biopsy of this lesion is most likely to demonstrate which of the following pathological changes?
questions.solution:
This patient with symptoms of chronic, worsening gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is at an increased risk of developing Barrett esophagus. An upper endoscopy study will show erythematous mucosa (also referred to as salmon-colored mucosa) at the junction of the esophagus and stomach. Barrett esophagus refers to metaplasia of the normal squamous epithelium of the distal esophagus to columnar epithelium with goblet cells due to prolonged acidic content exposure. Biopsies will reveal a transition from stratified squamous epithelium to columnar epithelium with goblet cells as detailed in the histologic image below:  



Reproduced from: Wikipedia  

Barrett esophagus is considered premalignant esophageal adenocarcinoma, the most common esophageal carcinoma in the United States. Patients with Barrett esophagus should have an upper endoscopy study every five years to monitor for progression of metaplasia into dysplastic tissue. Treatment includes proton pump inhibitors and H2 receptor blockers; however, patients who still experience symptoms of acid reflux despite medical therapy may require surgical management.  

Option Analysis

✅ Columnar epithelium with goblet cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Columnar epithelium with cilia:
Incorrect: The trachea and bronchi are lined with columnar epithelium and cilia. The motile nature of the cilia allows for the expulsion of particles in the respiratory tract. Histology will also show goblet cells and club cells.  
❌ Columnar epithelium with parietal cells:
Incorrect: Parietal cells are specialized cells which normally line the fundus and body of the stomach and are not generally found in the metaplasia of Barrett esophagus. Parietal cells produce stomach acid and release intrinsic factor for vitamin B12 absorption and are modulated by gastrin, histamine, and acetylcholine.   
❌ Non-keratinized squamous epithelium:
Incorrect: The esophagus is normally lined with non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. The epithelium undergoes rapid turnover and serves to protect the inner layers of the esophagus from mechanical abrasion during swallowing.   
❌ Transitional epithelium:
Incorrect: Transitional epithelium consists of basal, intermediate, and superficial cell layers. These cells line the ureters and bladder and play an important role in allowing for distension and contraction of these tissues.

A 69-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with dysphagia. The patient reports progressive difficulty swallowing, now to the point where he has trouble tolerating liquids and sometimes vomits after eating. The patient has a significant history of alcohol abuse, 50-pack-year smoking history, as well as hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 14/min and blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg. Physical exam shows a thin male with bitemporal wasting and non-tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Oral and neck examination is unremarkable aside from poor dentition. Laboratory results are as follows:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
CBC, Serum 
 Hemoglobin  11.2  g/dL 
 Hematocrit  33.6% 
 Leukocyte count  10,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  149,000/mm3 
 MCV                        72 fL 
 RDW                    11.5-14.5% 
 Iron Studies, Serum  
          Serum Iron                     90 μg/dL  
             Ferritin            Ferritin 170 ng/mL  
 Total iron binding capacity                               220 μg/dL 
A barium swallow study reveals an esophageal mass that significantly narrows the lumen in the middle of the esophagus. Which of the following pathologic features is most likely to be found on upper endoscopy?

choices.text: Columnar dysplasia with goblet cell crowding and invasion into the lamina propria
Invasion of neoplastic squamous cells into the lamina propria
Loss of inhibitory ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus

questions.solution:
This patient with a significant smoking and alcohol abuse history, cachexia, lymphadenopathy and microcytic anemia raises concern for esophageal carcinoma, of which the squamous cell variant is most likely.  

Esophageal carcinoma gets divided into two types: squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma. In general, the two variants are clinically indistinguishable, but typically present with weight loss and progressive difficulty swallowing. Laboratory results may show either an anemia of chronic disease pattern, as in this patient, or iron deficiency anemia due to chronic blood loss from the invading tumor.    

Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common variant worldwide and is attributable to >95% of cases. It most commonly occurs in the upper or middle 2/3 of the esophagus, with alcohol abuse and smoking as the greatest risk factors. Adenocarcinoma typically occurs in the lower or distal third of the esophagus and is a consequence of untreated Barrett esophagus due to long-standing gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Treatment of the cancer depends on both grade and stage but generally involves a combination of both surgery and chemo-radiation.    

Option Analysis

❌ Columnar metaplasia with goblet cells :
Incorrect: Columnar metaplasia with goblet cells describes the pathohistology of Barrett esophagus, the precursor to adenocarcinoma of the esophagus. This older patient presenting with cachexia, a significant history of alcohol and tobacco use, and an esophageal mass more likely has a neoplastic process occurring.
❌ Columnar dysplasia with goblet cell crowding and invasion into the lamina propria:
Incorrect: This describes the features of adenocarcinoma of the esophagus. While difficult to distinguish clinically, this cancer variant is less likely in this patient with a strong history of smoking and alcohol一the most significant risk factors for squamous cell cancer of the esophagus. Additionally, the location of this patient’s esophageal mass in the upper 2/3 of the esophagus is suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus. 
✅ Invasion of neoplastic squamous cells into the lamina propria:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Loss of inhibitory ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus:
Incorrect: Achalasia is a process due to loss of inhibitory ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus. While possible, it remains a diagnosis of exclusion and is less likely in an older patient with a mass and systemic findings concerning for underlying malignancy. 
❌ Eosinophilic predominance and basophilic hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Eosinophilic esophagitis occurs in all age groups and especially in patients with other atopic disorders such as asthma and eczema. Patients typically present with upper abdominal pain and food impaction.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man comes to the clinic due to intermittent difficulty swallowing for the past few months. The patient describes intermittent difficulty swallowing solids, which is often relieved by drinking fluids and after self-induced regurgitation. There is no associated weight loss or fatigue. Medical history is notable for a sliding hiatal hernia, hypertension, and long term gastroesophageal reflux disease. Medications include proton pump inhibitors and thiazides. The patient does not smoke or use alcohol or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. The rest of the physical examination is normal. Endoscopy is performed, and the results are equivocal. Barium esophagogram is obtained and reveals the following:  


 

Reproduced from: Radiopaedia

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a long history of gastroesophageal reflux disease is now presenting with intermittent dysphagia to solids. The barium swallow test reveals distal, symmetric, circumferential narrowing of the esophagus, favoring the diagnosis of a Schatzki ring.   

Schatzki rings (esophageal rings) are concentric bands of mucosa and submucosa that typically occur at the lower esophagus. The etiology is unknown but has been mostly associated with chronic damage from gastroesophageal reflux. Schatzki rings are almost always associated with hiatal hernias. Patients typically present with intermittent dysphagia to solids, although some may be asymptomatic depending on the size of the ring. Diagnosis is made with an endoscopy or barium swallow test (more sensitive), showing a concentric band of mucosa, protruding into the lumen. On biopsy, rings are composed of mucosa and submucosa, hyperkeratosis and occasional eosinophils. Biopsy is always performed on endoscopy because Schatzki rings are often associated with eosinophilic esophagitis. Treatment consists of proton pump inhibitors and surgical intervention (e.g. balloon, myomectomy).  

Option Analysis

❌ Esophageal carcinoma:
Incorrect: Esophageal carcinoma typically presents with progressive dysphagia to solids initially, followed by dysphagia to liquids, and it is usually accompanied by weight loss. The most common types are squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma. Esophageal carcinoma typically presents as an irregular mass on endoscopy and/or on a barium swallow test. This patient’s presentation and imaging favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Esophageal stricture:
Incorrect: Esophageal stricture is caused by fibrotic changes in the esophagus most commonly caused by gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Similar to rings, it presents with symptoms of dysphagia; however, strictures are longer in axial length and have tapered ends rather than symmetrical concentric narrowing.   
✅ Esophageal ring:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Esophageal web:
Incorrect: An esophageal web is a thin mucosal membrane that grows into the esophageal lumen and may cause dysphagia. Esophageal webs are often missed on upper endoscopy because of their proximity to the upper esophageal sphincter. Esophageal webs are more common in the proximal esophagus and are usually not circumferential. Webs are also associated with Plummer-Vinson syndrome.   
❌ Achalasia :
Incorrect: Achalasia is a motility disorder of the esophagus caused by degeneration on the inhibitory neurons in the esophageal wall, resulting in dysphagia to both solids and liquids. Barium swallow typically shows distal stenosis (“bird’s beak”), rather than symmetrical circumferential narrowing.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man comes to the office due to dysphagia accompanied by food impaction and upper abdominal pain for the past few months. He had tried multiple over the counter antacids with minimal relief. Past medical history is notable for gastroesophageal reflux disease and seasonal allergies. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 10 years. An endoscopy is performed, and the results are shown below:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely pathogenesis involved in this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Transient decreases in lower esophageal sphincter tone

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of atopy (e.g. allergies) is presenting with dysphagia, food impaction, and upper abdominal pain. Along with the endoscopy results showing stacked circular rings ("feline" esophagus) and refractoriness to antacid therapy, the most likely diagnosis is eosinophilic esophagitis.   

Eosinophilic esophagitis is a chronic, atopic, inflammatory disease of the esophagus. The condition is frequently seen in men aged 20-40 but may also be seen in children. Patients typically present with complaints such as dysphagia, food impaction, chest pain unresponsive to antacids, refractory GERD, and upper abdominal pain. Patients typically have an atopic history (e.g., asthma, dermatitis). The diagnosis of eosinophilic esophagitis is based on the symptoms, endoscopic appearance, and histological findings.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Loss of postganglionic inhibitory neurons:
Incorrect: Loss of postganglionic inhibitory neurons is the pathogenesis behind achalasia, which is characterized by progressive dysphagia to solids and liquids. An upper endoscopy may reveal a dilated esophagus and difficulty passing through the lower esophageal sphincter. Barium swallow would likely show a dilated esophagus with an area of distal stenosis (“bird’s beak”).   
✅ Eosinophilic infiltration of the esophagus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transient decreases in lower esophageal sphincter tone:
Incorrect: Transient decreases in lower esophageal sphincter tone is the pathogenesis behind gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Patients typically present with heartburn, regurgitation, dysphagia, and occasional cough or hoarseness. Although this patient has some features of GERD, the symptoms have been unresponsive to antacid treatment, and the endoscopy results favor another diagnosis. 
❌ Smooth muscle atrophy:
Incorrect: Smooth muscle atrophy is the pathogenesis behind sclerodermal esophageal dysmotility, which can present as reflux, dysphagia, aspiration, and strictures. However, other systemic symptoms would be expected (i.e., calcinosis, Raynaud's phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia [CREST]).   
❌ Iron deficiency anemia:
Incorrect: Iron deficiency anemia is the mechanism behind Plummer-Vinson syndrome, which presents with a classic triad of dysphagia, iron deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs (as seen in the endoscopic image below). Other symptoms may include glossitis, angular cheilitis, koilonychia, splenomegaly, and symptoms of iron deficiency anemia (e.g., fatigue, conjunctival pallor). This patient's presentation favors another diagnosis.    


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with significant abdominal pain. The patient reports intermittent, worsening upper abdominal pain after eating.  She initially saw her primary care physician when the symptoms began several months ago and had a negative work up that included a normal urea breath test, liver function tests, and lipase. Yesterday, the patient noticed that her stools were darker than normal, and she felt like she was going to faint at home. Past medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis, hypertension, and hyperthyroidism. Medications include naproxen, synthroid, and hydrochlorothiazide. Temperature is  37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 107/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 100/82 mmHg. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium. Laboratory values are shown below:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
CBC, Serum
 Hemoglobin  11.2  g/dL 
 Hematocrit  33.6% 
 Leukocyte count  12,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  149,000/mm3 
 MCV                        72 fL 
 RDW                    11.5-14.5% 
 Serum
               Sodium  134 mEq/L 
           Potassium  4.2 mEq/L 
              Chloride  97 mEq/L 
                 BUN                    40 mg/dL  
             Creatinine  2.2 mg/dL 
              Albumin  3.1  g/dL 
Which of the following best summarizes the pathophysiology of this patient’s disease process?

choices.text: Mucosal degradation caused by Gram-negative bacteria

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of chronic naproxen use, epigastric pain, and symptomatic anemia with an elevated BUN raises concern for a bleeding peptic ulcer due to chronic NSAID use. The laboratory results demonstrate an elevated BUN due to an increase in hemoglobin digestion as it passes through the GI tract. Additionally, the patient’s vital signs demonstrate tachycardia and borderline hypotension concerning for large volume blood loss.  

NSAIDs including naproxen, aspirin, ketorolac, and diclofenac inhibit cyclooxygenase or COX, which mediates the production of prostaglandins. In the stomach, prostaglandins are produced by COX-1, as opposed to COX-2 which is expressed constitutively throughout the body. Prostaglandins in the stomach, especially PGE2, help to maintain the barrier function of gastric mucosa by enhancing bicarbonate secretion, mucous production, epithelial hyperplasia, as well as mucosal blood flow via vasodilation. As the barrier function breaks down due to NSAID-induced COX inhibition, gastric acid erodes the mucosa, eventually leading to gastritis or ulcer formation. If left untreated, gastric ulcers can cause significant gastrointestinal bleeding and anemia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Mucosal degradation caused by Gram-negative bacteria :
Incorrect: H. pylori degrades gastric mucosa via several mechanisms, including secretion of H. pylori proteases, such as vacuolating cytotoxin A. This protease damages epithelial cells, disrupts tight junctions and causes apoptosis with subsequent mucosal degradation. H. pylori peptic ulcer disease is less likely given this patient’s negative urea breath test.
✅ Inhibition of a cyclooxygenase enzyme :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ischemia of gastric vasculature:
Incorrect: Ischemia of gastric vasculature describes the pathophysiology of a Curling ulcer, which is more commonly found in cases of severe burns and in mechanically ventilated ICU patients. Decreased blood flow to the gastric mucosa results in inappropriate buffering of the acidic environment and ulcer formation.
❌ Oversecretion of gastrin :
Incorrect: Overproduction of gastrin describes the pathophysiology of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, a rare gastrin-secreting pancreatic tumor. Zollinger-Ellison syndrome typically presents with additional constitutional symptoms including weight loss, malaise and cachexia.  
❌ Autoantibodies directed at intrinsic factor :
Incorrect: Autoantibodies directed at intrinsic factor describe the pathophysiology of chronic autoimmune gastritis. This disease may cause gastric ulcerations; however, it more typically presents with macrocytic anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency, as opposed to a microcytic anemia as seen in this patient.

A 37-year-old woman with a history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis presents to the primary care physician with a several-month history of fatigue and pain after eating. The patient reports burning pain approximately twenty to thirty minutes after every meal with associated nausea. She reports that she drinks one glass of wine with dinner every night. She does not have worsening of the symptoms with any particular food items, and she has not had any recent changes in diet.  Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 14/min and blood pressure is 110/62 mmHg. Physical exam shows conjunctival pallor as well as a smoothened and shiny tongue, fissures at the angles of the lips, and a wide-based gait. Laboratory findings are demonstrated below:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 CBC, Serum 
 Hemoglobin  10.2  g/dL 
 Hematocrit  33.6% 
 Leukocyte count  9,000 /mm3 
 Platelet count  200,000/mm3 
 MCV                        109 fL 
 RDW                    11.5-14.5% 
 Serum 
               Sodium  134 mEq/L 
           Potassium  4.2 mEq/L 
              Chloride  96 mEq/L 
                 BUN                    37 mg/dL 
             Creatinine  1.8 mg/dL 
              Albumin  3.5  g/dL 
Which of the following best describes the mechanism underlying this patient’s clinical manifestations?

choices.text: Colonization of the gastric mucosa with a Gram-negative bacteria
Autoantibodies directed against a protein produced by chief cells
Autoantibodies directed against a glycoprotein produced by parietal cells

questions.solution:
This patient has a history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis and is presenting with a several month history of fatigue, abdominal pain, and macrocytic anemia. The physical examination shows angular cheilitis and an ataxic gait. This constellation of findings are concerning for pernicious anemia due to chronic autoimmune gastritis or type A gastritis.  

Chronic autoimmune gastritis occurs when the patient’s immune system produces antibodies targeting both intrinsic factor and parietal cells, an example of a type IV hypersensitivity reaction. Over time, this leads to chronic mucosal inflammation, atrophy and fibrosis, as well as impaired secretion of hydrochloric acid. Loss of intrinsic factor results in an inability to absorb vitamin B12, resulting in signs and symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency, such as fatigue, numbness, and gait disturbance due to degeneration of the posterior and lateral columns of the spinal cord.   

Most patients with chronic autoimmune gastritis are asymptomatic until they develop pernicious anemia, with fatigue being the most common symptom. Diagnosis of chronic autoimmune gastritis is made by endoscopy with biopsy, which will show atrophy of the gastric mucosa, loss of glandular cells, and their replacement with metaplastic epithelium in only the body and fundus of the stomach. This is in contrast to chronic gastritis due to H. pylori, which would show multiple areas of atrophy, metaplasia, and inflammation most heavily concentrated near the antrum of the stomach. Supporting information to make the diagnosis of pernicious anemia includes the presence of anti-intrinsic factor antibodies and increased serum gastrin levels.  

Option Analysis

❌ Colonization of the gastric mucosa with a Gram-negative bacteria:
Incorrect: H. pylori is a common cause of chronic gastritis, and patients also often present with chronic dyspepsia, but they are less likely to suffer from pernicious anemia. This patient with risk factors for additional autoimmune disease and laboratory results showing megaloblastic anemia is less likely to be suffering from H. pylori gastritis. 
❌ Autoantibodies directed against gliadin:
Incorrect: This describes anti-gliadin antibodies, one of the biological markers used in the diagnosis of celiac disease. Patients with celiac disease can develop pernicious anemia, but they typically report a history of abdominal pain worse after eating gluten-containing food items, as well as a history of chronic diarrhea. 
❌ Alcohol-induced megaloblastic anemia:
Incorrect: Alcohol by itself can induce a macrocytic anemia due to its direct toxic effects on bone marrow. However, this diagnosis is one of exclusion and only occurs with chronic heavy alcohol use. 
❌ Autoantibodies directed against a protein produced by chief cells :
Incorrect: The autoantibodies produced in chronic autoimmune gastritis are directed at parietal cells, not chief cells. 
✅ Autoantibodies directed against a glycoprotein produced by parietal cells :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient had spent the evening at a bar with friends and consumed 7-10 shots of liquor. Shortly after leaving the bar, he felt nauseated and vomited multiple times. The last episode of vomiting produced bright red emesis. The patient denies dyspnea or recent trauma. Past medical history is notable for asthma, for which he takes albuterol as needed. His vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a thin male in mild distress. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are noncontributory. The patient has no additional episodes of hematemesis. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Sodium  139 mg/dL 
 Potassium  3.8 mg/dL 
 Chloride  100 mg/dL 
 Bicarbonate  33 mg/dL 
Which of the following would be most useful in providing a definitive diagnosis of the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has Mallory-Weiss syndrome, also termed gastro-esophageal laceration syndrome, which manifests as longitudinal, partial-thickness mucosal tears at the gastroesophageal junction. The condition most often occurs due to forceful vomiting, which increases intra-abdominal pressure. Additionally, in this patient, the repeated vomiting has caused a metabolic alkalosis.  

While vomiting is one of the most common causes, Mallory-Weiss syndrome can also be due to coughing, abdominal trauma, or abdominal straining. Patients with hiatal hernias are also at increased risk of developing Mallory-Weiss syndrome; one proposed explanation is that the hernia experiences a greater pressure gradient than the rest of the stomach. Additional risk factors include alcoholism and patients with eating disorders who exhibit purging behaviors since these conditions increase the risk of frequent, forceful vomiting and retching.  

Individuals with Mallory-Weiss syndrome can be asymptomatic, or they can present with painful hematemesis. A barium swallow can be performed and may show hematomas or streaks in the esophagus. However, endoscopy is required to confirm the mucosal tears and provide a definitive diagnosis.    

In most cases, Mallory-Weiss syndrome spontaneously resolves. However, if there is severe bleeding, endoscopic techniques are needed to achieve hemostasis.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Chest radiograph:
Incorrect: A chest radiograph is useful in the work-up of patients with esophageal perforation and will show free air. Esophageal perforation will cause dyspnea, severe chest pain, crepitus on palpation, and crackles on auscultation. In contrast, this patient has none of the aforementioned symptoms.
❌ Esophageal barium swallow:
Incorrect: An esophageal barium swallow study can reveal mucosal lacerations. However, upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy is more accurate and is necessary to definitively diagnose the patient’s condition, a Mallory-Weiss tear.
✅ Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Computed tomography of the chest  :
Incorrect: This patient’s symptom of upper GI bleeding after heavy drinking and vomiting raises concerns for a Mallory-Weiss tear. The absence of crepitus makes full-thickness esophageal perforation unlikely. Since Mallory-Weiss tears are partial-thickness lacerations, they will most likely be radiographically occult and thus are often missed on a CT scan.
❌ Blood alcohol level:
Incorrect: This patient has been consuming large quantities of alcohol and will have an elevated blood alcohol level. However, this test will not help differentiate the different potential sources of upper GI bleeding (e.g., Mallory-Weiss syndrome, Boerhaave syndrome, gastric ulcer).

He states he has had abdominal pain for the past several weeks, with the pain acutely worsening today with radiation to the left shoulder. He was also admitted for alcoholic pancreatitis approximately six weeks ago.The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He reports drinking 3-4 beers daily. Temperature is 37°C (98.6 °F), pulse is 111/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 92/62 mmHg. Physical examination shows a pale man in acute distress. Abdominal examination is notable for diffuse tenderness to palpation, with rebound and rigidity. Laboratory results are shown below:

Abdominal imaging is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?
