Dilation of the abdominal aorta >5 cm

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a peritonitis, coffee ground emesis, and signs of hemodynamic instability concerning for a perforated ulcer. In the setting of peritonitis, an upright chest x-ray should be performed on all patients to rule out free air under the diaphragm from a perforated viscus. If free air is discovered, urgent surgical consultation should be obtained for exploration and repair.  

Peptic ulcer disease is the most common cause of gastric and duodenal perforations, and they are typically located on the anterior or superior portions of the duodenum. Most patients will describe acute on chronic onset of abdominal pain with referred pain to the shoulder via irritation of the phrenic nerve. The majority of perforations due to peptic ulcer disease require repair with either an open or laparoscopic approach.  

Option Analysis

✅ Subdiaphragmatic air :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pericholecystic fluid and common bile duct dilatation:
Incorrect: Acute cholecystitis may manifest with signs and symptoms of peritonitis in the setting of perforation. The absence of focal right upper quadrant tenderness makes this diagnosis less likely. 
❌ Mediastinal emphysema:
Incorrect: Boerhaave syndrome or esophageal rupture typically presents with forceful retching and vomiting followed by severe retrosternal chest pain. Typical physical exam findings include crepitus over the chest wall and Hamman’s sign, where mediastinal crackling with each heartbeat may be heard on auscultation. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with an abdominal pathology.
❌ Dilation of the abdominal aorta >5 cm:
Incorrect: Patients with an aortic rupture typically present with lower back pain, a pulsatile abdominal mass, and a bruit on auscultation. With the absence of these clinical signs, this patient is less likely to be suffering from an abdominal aortic aneurysm.
❌ Pseudocyst surrounding the pancreas :
Incorrect: Pancreatic pseudocysts may manifest four to six weeks after an episode of pancreatitis. Typically, these present with persistent abdominal pain and indigestion after a bout of pancreatitis. Rarely do these present with peritonitis or hemodynamic instability, unless there is severe co-existing necrosis or hemorrhage. Additionally, pancreatic pseudocysts tend to present with persistently elevated lipase.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman comes to the office due to difficulty swallowing, food regurgitation, and reflux for the past several months. The patient describes difficulty swallowing both liquids and solids. She occasionally regurgitates chunks of undigested food. Medical history is unremarkable except for a C-section 8 years ago. She has had no recent illness, weight loss or fatigue, and she does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. She drinks alcohol socially. She has not traveled out of the country recently. A barium swallow test is performed and shown below:  

 


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following patterns is most likely to be seen in this patient on manometry of the esophagus?
questions.solution:
This patient has achalasia. The barium swallow test results show characteristic dilated esophagus with distal stenosis (“bird’s beak”).  

Deglutition (swallowing) is a complex process that involves a series of synchronized voluntary and involuntary muscle contractions. It is divided into the oral, pharyngeal, and esophageal phases. In short, the food is chewed into bolus and propagated by the tongue towards the pharynx. The bolus is then transited to the pharynx and pushed into the esophagus by sequential contraction of pharyngeal constrictor muscles. The bolus enters the esophagus and by waves of peristalsis moves downwards. The lower esophageal sphincter relaxes to allow food into the stomach.    

Achalasia is a functional disorder of the esophagus resulting from inflammation and degeneration of neurons in the esophageal wall. The condition preferentially affects the myenteric (Auerbach) postganglionic inhibitory neurons which contain nitric oxide and vasoactive intestinal peptide (which promote relaxation). The cholinergic neurons that contribute to lower esophageal sphincter (LES) tone by smooth muscle contraction are relatively spared. The result is decreased peristalsis movement in the distal esophagus and the absence of relaxation of the LES, resulting in dysphagia to both liquids and solids. Achalasia can be primary (idiopathic) or secondary (e.g. Chagas disease).  



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: This manometry result is consistent with scleroderma esophageal dysmotility. In patients with scleroderma, there is smooth muscle atrophy that results in decreased pressure and dysmotility of the lower esophageal sphincter. Patients often complain of acid reflux and dysphagia; however, other features of the condition would be expected (e.g., CREST syndrome: Calcinosis cutis, anti-Centromere antibody, Raynaud phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasia).   
✅ B:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ C:
Incorrect: This manometry result is consistent with diffuse esophageal spasm, a medical condition characterized by uncoordinated esophageal contractions that present as dysphagia, regurgitation and chest pain. The pain often simulates myocardial ischemia but without relation to exertion. There is no relationship to food, but it can be triggered by cold fluids. Barium study may show a “corkscrew”’ pattern at the time of the spasm, not a “bird’s beak” pattern as seen in this patient. On manometry, high intensity, disorganized contractions are typically seen.  
❌ D:
Incorrect: This manometry result is consistent with hypercontractile (nutcracker) esophagus, a motility disorder of the esophagus characterized by normal peristalsis pattern but in an excessive amplitude or duration. Similar to diffuse esophageal spasm, patients also complain of dysphagia and chest pain (it may mimic MI). The pathogenesis is thought to be due to excessive excitation and smooth muscle hypertrophy.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man is intubated in the intensive care unit after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle accident and sustaining burns to greater than 50% of his total body surface area. He undergoes several surgeries including skin grafts and exploratory laparotomy with bowel resection. On the 5th day of admission, he is noted to have worsening abdominal distension and dark stool in the rectal tube. Temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 121/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 90/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on 50% FiO2. Physical examination shows an intubated, ill-appearing man with extensive burns and capillary refill >3 seconds. A chest x-ray is obtained and shown below:  


 Reproduced from: Wikipedia 

Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Anastomotic leak at the site of bowel resection
Reduced plasma volume and gastric mucosal sloughing
Ongoing hemorrhage from a vascular ectasia

questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette, who is presenting with signs of hemodynamic instability, an ongoing upper gastrointestinal bleed, and free air under the diaphragm, likely has a gastric perforation due to ulcer formation. Gastric ulcer development is common in mechanically ventilated intensive care unit patients, particularly in patients with extensive burn injuries or elevated intracranial pressure.    

This patient likely has a Curling ulcer, a type of ulcer that develops in response to low circulating plasma volume, commonly seen in patients with extensive burn injuries, sepsis, or hemorrhage.  Burn patients have massive insensible volume losses, causing decreased circulating volume, and subsequent ischemia to the gastric mucosa. With prolonged ischemia, the gastric mucosa sloughs off and acidic secretions erode the stomach until full thickness perforation occurs. Free air under the diaphragm can be seen in this patient, as the highlighted area underneath the right diaphragm on imaging.  



Patients with traumatic brain injuries, brain tumors, and elevated intracranial pressure can develop Cushing’s ulcers, which are thought to result from overstimulation of the vagus nerve. With stimulation of the vagus nerve, efferent fibers release acetylcholine activating M3 receptors on gastric parietal cells, causing excess hydrogen ion secretion and an imbalance of gastric pH.  

Due to the high incidence of ulcers in mechanically ventilated patients with these conditions, it is common practice to place them on ulcer prophylaxis, usually with a proton pump inhibitor.    

Option Analysis

❌ Direct stimulation of vagal nuclei :
Incorrect: This describes the pathophysiology of a Cushing ulcer, which results from prolonged vagal stimulation due to increased intracranial pressure. The increased vagal tone results in increased production of stomach acid via acetylcholine release. Cushing ulcers more commonly occur in patients with traumatic head injuries and intracranial malignancies.   
❌ Anastomotic leak at the site of bowel resection:
Incorrect: An anastomotic leak can result in hemodynamic instability; however it is less likely to result in free air under the diaphragm with associated melena.  
✅ Reduced plasma volume and gastric mucosal sloughing :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Ongoing hemorrhage from a vascular ectasia:
Incorrect: Vascular ectasias such as a Dieulafoy lesion (abnormal submucosal artery that is vulnerable to lesions) present with symptoms of upper gastrointestinal bleeding, but these conditions are unlikely to present with pneumoperitoneum.  
❌ Subphrenic abscess :
Incorrect: A subphrenic abscess is in the differential diagnosis of pneumoperitoneum. However, these patient’s will typically present with fevers in addition to other signs of hemodynamic instability.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician with a several month history of burning epigastric pain and nausea that is worse after eating. The patient reports she has lost approximately 15 pounds (6.8 kg) due to pain with eating. The patient’s only other medical problem is chronic shoulder arthritis for which she takes naproxen daily. The patient undergoes endoscopy with biopsy of the following pathologic lesion:  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

From which area of the gastrointestinal tract was this biopsy most likely taken?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with pain worse with eating, weight loss, chronic NSAID use, as well as a gastric ulcer with surrounding rugae, likely in the body or fundus of the stomach.   

Peptic ulcer disease is classified based on its anatomic location, either duodenal or gastric. Gastric ulcers are most commonly due to H. pylori or NSAIDs, whereas duodenal ulcers are almost exclusively due to H. pylori (>90% of cases). In either case, dysfunction of the mucosal barrier leads to increased permeability to gastric acid secretion. In the rare case of duodenal ulcers due to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, a rare gastrin-secreting tumor, gastric acid production is also augmented.  

If left untreated, gastric ulcers can perforate, bleed, and have a higher rate of developing into gastric cancer. For this reason, all gastric ulcers are biopsied on upper endoscopy to evaluate for any histologic features of malignancy

 

Option Analysis

✅ Fundus of the stomach:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Esophagus:
Incorrect: Ulceration of the esophagus is typically viral in etiology, with CMV or HSV as common agents. The image obtained from endoscopy in this patient demonstrates an ulcer with surrounding rugae, which is not likely to be seen in the esophagus.   
❌ Duodenum :
Incorrect: Duodenal ulcers present with pain that is relieved upon eating, pain at night, and oftentimes weight gain. Endoscopy will typically show ulcers surrounded by the circular folds of the small intestine.   
❌ Gastroesophageal junction:
Incorrect: The gastroesophageal junction is implicated in Barrett esophagus. This metaplastic process occurs when the stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by columnar epithelium and goblet cells due to uncontrolled acid reflux.  
❌ Cardia of the stomach:
Incorrect: The cardia is the area just adjacent to the gastroesophageal junction. It is an uncommon site for the development of gastric ulcers.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with a several month history of epigastric abdominal discomfort. The patient describes a burning sensation after eating, abdominal fullness, and distension. He reports taking omeprazole for the symptoms without relief. An endoscopy with biopsy is performed demonstrating the following histologic specimen:  



Reproduced from: Wikipedia

From which area of the gastrointestinal tract was this biopsy most likely taken?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of chronic dyspepsia and a biopsy demonstrating Gram negative bacteria with surrounding metaplasia concerning for type B chronic gastritis due to Helicobacter Pylori. A distinguishing diagnostic feature of H. pylori gastritis when compared to chronic autoimmune gastritis is the location of the metaplasia and atrophy seen on histologic specimens. Most patients with chronic gastritis due to H. pylori will demonstrate these pathologic changes in the antrum of the stomach, whereas patients with chronic autoimmune gastritis will have these changes primarily in the body/fundus.  

Clinically, chronic H. pylori gastritis presents with symptoms of dyspepsia over weeks to months but may go unrecognized entirely. H. pylori preferentially invades the antrum to avoid the acidic secretions by parietal cells in the fundus and body. In the antrum, colonization by the bacteria drives proliferation and increased secretion of gastrin by G-cells. Gastrin stimulates parietal cells to secrete additional hydrochloric acid, eroding the gastric mucosa and causing atrophy and loss of glandular cells with replacement by metaplastic epithelium. Colonization in the antrum also damages delta cells, involved in the secretion of somatostatin. With decreased somatostatin levels, gastrin becomes uninhibited, leading to increased secretion of acid by parietal cells.  With continued inflammation, MALT lymphoma, a tumor of mucosa associated lymphoid tissue, can arise.   

Option Analysis

❌ Fundus of the stomach:
Incorrect: The fundus is the most common area of the stomach affected by chronic autoimmune gastritis, which typically presents in patients with additional autoimmune disorders and pernicious anemia.   
❌ Gastroesophageal junction:
Incorrect: The gastroesophageal junction is implicated in Barrett esophagus. This metaplastic process occurs when stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by columnar epithelium and goblet cells due to uncontrolled acid reflux.  
❌ Duodenum :
Incorrect: Duodenal ulcers may occur following infection with H. pylori; however, it is not the most common site of colonization by the bacteria.   
✅ Antrum of the stomach:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Esophagus :
Incorrect: The esophagus is not a common location for colonization of H. pylori.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after an episode of hematemesis. The patient had spent the night at a bar drinking with his colleagues. After leaving the bar, he vomited multiple times and noticed bright-red blood mixed with the vomitus, and he called an ambulance. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, for which he is taking lisinopril. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a patient in no acute distress. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are non-contributory. Which of the following additional findings will most likely develop in this patient?

choices.text: Passage of bright-red blood from the anus

questions.solution:
This patient likely has a Mallory-Weiss tear, which is characterized by lacerations of the esophageal mucosa secondary to forceful and repeated vomiting. Mallory-Weiss tears can lead to gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding.  

GI bleeding can be divided into upper and lower bleeding. Upper GI bleeding arises above the ligament of Treitz (also termed suspensory ligament of the duodenum), and the term includes bleeding from the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum. Symptoms include hematemesis (vomiting of fresh red blood), ‘coffee ground’ vomitus (vomiting of blood that has been oxidized by stomach acids), and melena (black and tarry stools). However, if the upper GI bleeding is brisk enough, it is possible to also have bright red blood in the stool following a presentation with melena.  

In contrast, lower GI bleeding arises below the ligament of Treitz and includes bleeding from the small intestine distal to the duodenum, large intestines, rectum, and anus. Typical presentation includes hematochezia (fresh blood passing through the anus).  

If individuals lose significant quantities of blood via GI bleeding, they can develop anemia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Black tarry stools:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Passage of bright-red blood from the anus:
Incorrect: Patients with a lower gastrointestinal (GI) bleed may notice bright-red blood mixed with their stool. In contrast, this patient most likely has a Mallory-Weiss tear, which is an upper GI bleed caused by forceful and repeated vomiting. Blood from an upper GI bleed will have oxidized by the time it is expelled and will thus appear dark in color.  
❌ Foul-smelling oily stools:
Incorrect: Foul-smelling and oily stools may be observed in patients with fat malabsorption, which can be due to various conditions, ranging from pancreatic insufficiency to Giardia infection. However, it would be atypical for patients to develop this symptom after an episode of GI bleeding.  
❌ Abdominal pain exacerbated with eating:
Incorrect: Patients with gastric ulcers have abdominal pain that is worsened by food intake. Gastric ulcers can cause an upper GI bleed and lead to hematemesis. However, this patient's history of bleeding after multiple episodes of vomiting is more consistent with a Mallory-Weiss tear.   
❌ Sloughed mucosa mixed with stool  :
Incorrect: This describes “currant-jelly stools,” which occur when sloughed mucosa, blood, and mucus are mixed with the stool. The symptom is often found in patients with intestinal ischemia or intussusception, both of which can lead to lower GI bleeding. In contrast, this patient has upper GI bleeding. Blood from an upper GI bleed will have oxidized by the time it is expelled with stool.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the office due to difficulty swallowing, food regurgitation, and chest pain for the past several months. The patient describes difficulty swallowing both liquids and solids. He often regurgitates large pieces of undigested food mixed with saliva. History is notable for drinking 2 beers every evening and smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 5 years. He has had no recent illness, weight loss, or fatigue. He has not traveled out of the country recently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination, including cardiopulmonary examination, is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with dysphagia to both fluid and solids, regurgitation of big chunks of food mixed with saliva (implying food has not reached to the stomach), which favors the diagnosis of achalasia.  

Achalasia is a functional disorder of the esophagus resulting from inflammation and degeneration of neurons in the esophageal wall. In particular, the condition preferentially affects the myenteric (Auerbach) postganglionic inhibitory neurons, which contain nitric oxide and vasoactive intestinal peptide (which promote relaxation). The cholinergic neurons that contribute to lower esophageal sphincter (LES) tone by smooth muscle contraction are relatively spared. The result is decreased peristalsis movement in the distal esophagus and absence of relaxation of the LES, resulting in dysphagia to both liquids and solids. Achalasia can be primary (idiopathic) or secondary (e.g. Chagas disease).  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Globus sensation:
Incorrect: Globus sensation is a sensation of a lump or foreign body in the throat in the absence of symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease or other esophageal motility disorder. Although a definitive diagnosis requires further investigation, this patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Esophageal cancer:
Incorrect: Esophageal cancer typically presents with progressively worsening dysphagia (dysphagia to solids initially followed by food later in the course). The most common types are squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma. Although this patient has significant risk factors for the condition, patients rarely present before the age of 55. Additionally, these symptoms favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Achalasia :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gastroesophageal reflux disease:
Incorrect: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) classically presents as heartburn and regurgitation. Other symptoms include dysphagia, chest pain, odynophagia, and extraesophageal symptoms (e.g., chronic cough, hoarseness). Patients often describe regurgitation of acidic material intermixed with small amounts of undigested food. This patient has dysphagia to both liquids and solids, as well as regurgitation of big chunks of food mixed with saliva, which favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Diffuse esophageal spasm:
Incorrect: Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) is a medical condition characterized by uncoordinated esophageal contractions that present as dysphagia, regurgitation, and chest pain. The pain often simulates myocardial ischemia but without relation to exertion. There is no relationship to food, but it can be triggered by cold fluids. Barium study may show a “corkscrew”’ pattern at the time of the spasm. Manometry typically shows high intensity, disorganized, simultaneous contractions.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found intoxicated on the sidewalk. She is arousable and reports she had several alcoholic drinks earlier that evening followed by multiple episodes of vomiting containing small amounts of blood. The patient reports stabbing epigastric and right upper quadrant abdominal pain for the past hour. She has no significant past medical history or previous surgeries but is currently on oral contraceptive therapy. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 149/82 mmHg.  Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium without rebound or guarding. Laboratory findings are as follows:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
CBC, Serum 
Hemoglobin  14.5  g/dL 
 Hematocrit  43.5% 
 Leukocyte count  10,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  249,000/mm3 
 MCV                        92 fL 
 RDW                    11.5-14.5% 
 Serum
               Sodium  134 mEq/L 
           Potassium  4.2 mEq/L 
              Chloride  98 mEq/L 
                 BUN                    18 mg/dL  
             Creatinine  .85 mg/dL 
              Albumin  3.7  g/dL 
               Lipase  90 U/L (N = 12-70 U/L) 
Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this disease process?

choices.text: Epithelial breakdown without penetration of the muscularis mucosa
Full thickness breakdown of the gastric mucosa

questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with acute abdominal pain following an episode of binge drinking with near normal laboratory values and epigastric pain, likely has acute gastritis. Gastritis or gastric erosions are described as gastric mucosal epithelial breakdown without full penetration into the muscularis mucosa. In contrast, gastric ulcers are noted to have full thickness breakdown of the mucosal epithelium with penetration into the muscularis mucosa.

Acute gastritis is typically caused by agents with a direct toxic effect on the gastric mucosa, which includes alcohol and NSAIDs. These agents work by decreasing bicarbonate secretion, mucous production, and epithelial hyperplasia, all of which ultimately contribute to mucosal epithelial breakdown. Typically, acute gastritis presents with acute onset of non-specific abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and occasionally metabolic derangements, whereas gastric ulcers usually present with progressive, intermittent abdominal pain, often with anemia due to chronic bleeding into the gastrointestinal tract.  

Option Analysis

❌ Ingestion of an enteral toxin  :
Incorrect: Staphylococcal food poisoning is caused by an enteral toxin with symptoms occurring approximately 6-10 hours after ingestions. Symptoms typically include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and low-grade temperature. This diagnosis is less likely given the patient’s history of recent alcohol ingestion.   
✅ Epithelial breakdown without penetration of the muscularis mucosa:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Full thickness breakdown of the gastric mucosa :
Incorrect: Full thickness breakdown of the gastric mucosa describes the pathophysiology of gastric ulcers. A gastric ulcer is unlikely in this patient without a previous history of progressive epigastric pain and with laboratory results showing a normal blood count. The blood in the vomitus is likely reflective of gastric erosion in the setting of acute gastritis.
❌ Hypertrophy of Brunner's glands :
Incorrect: Gastrin-secreting tumors (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome) result in hypertrophy of the Brunner glands. This is less likely in a young patient with no presenting signs of malignancy. 
❌ Hyperstimulation of pancreatic acinar cells:
Incorrect: Alcohol has a direct stimulant effect on pancreatic acinar cells, which is thought to be the underlying pathophysiology of pancreatitis in patients with chronic alcohol abuse. While the patient’s lipase is mildly elevated, a formal diagnosis of pancreatitis can typically only be made when the lipase is greater than three times the upper limit of normal. Pancreatitis would not explain the blood in the vomitus.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman begins complaining of chest pain in the post-anesthesia care unit after undergoing an upper endoscopy for evaluation of esophageal varices. She states the pain radiates to the back. She also complains of dyspnea, nausea, and she has produced blood-tinged vomitus. Past medical history is notable for chronic alcohol use disorder and liver cirrhosis. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 107/61 mmHg, and pulse is 82/min. Physical examination shows a woman in acute distress. Crackles are heard while auscultating over the heart. Abdominal exam is notable for hepatosplenomegaly. CT imaging reveals the following:  



Reproduced from: Radiopedia  

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Aspiration of gastric contents while unconscious

questions.solution:
This patient has an esophageal perforation, which can cause chest pain radiating to the back, vomiting, hematemesis, and melena. In addition, once esophageal perforation has occurred, it can lead to mediastinitis (inflammation of the mediastinum), pneumomediastinum (air surrounding the heart), and subcutaneous emphysema (presence of air in the subcutaneous tissue). Specifically, in this patient’s case, air has left the esophagus and accumulated in the mediastinum. This explains why crackles were heard during heart auscultation and why mediastinal air pockets are seen on CT (Figure 1).    

The causes of esophageal perforation can be divided into iatrogenic and non-iatrogenic causes. Perforation during endoscopic procedures is the most common iatrogenic cause. Non-iatrogenic causes include spontaneous rupture, trauma, foreign body ingestion, and malignancy.  

Diagnosis of esophageal rupture can be made using x-ray, which will show air that has escaped the esophagus, followed by a contrast esophagram, which will confirm the diagnosis, as well as determine the size and location of the perforation. A CT scan can be used in cases when a contrast esophagram cannot be performed (e.g. if a patient is hemodynamically unstable or uncooperative) or if the results come back inconclusive. Most cases typically require surgical management of the perforation.  

Image 1: Esophageal perforation with annotations (white arrows)  



Reproduced from: Radiopedia 

Option Analysis

❌ Anesthetic side-effect  :
Incorrect: Anesthetic agents may cause postoperative nausea and discomfort. However, anesthesia would not account for the crackles that were auscultated on physical exam or pneumomediastinum found on CT scan.  
✅ Iatrogenic perforation of the esophagus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Laceration of the esophageal mucosa:
Incorrect: It is possible for an endoscope to lacerate and cause bleeding from the esophageal mucosa. This would account for the patient’s blood-tinged vomitus. However, even if the mucosa were lacerated, the esophagus would still be surrounded by connective tissue and muscle. As a result, a mucosal laceration would not explain why this patient has air in the mediastinum.  
❌ Rupture of dilated esophageal veins:
Incorrect: Rupture of esophageal varices can cause upper GI bleeding, which can lead to nausea and vomiting. However, this mechanism would not account for the patient’s pneumomediastinum, which would occur only if a full-thickness esophageal perforation had occurred.  
❌ Aspiration of gastric contents while unconscious:
Incorrect: Anesthetized patients are at increased risk of aspiration pneumonia, in part due to reduced laryngeal protective reflexes. Patients may present with chest discomfort, dyspnea, cough, and fever. However the patient’s physical exam findings and imaging findings, which suggest the presence of air in the mediastinum, raise greater concerns for esophageal perforation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of difficulty swallowing accompanied by chest pain. The patient had a few of these episodes in the past but did not seek treatment. The episodes occur while he is having a meal, but only occasionally. He describes difficulty in swallowing both liquids and solids. He has not noticed any pain during exertion. Medical history is noncontributory. The patient does not smoke or use illicit drugs, and he drinks alcohol socially. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. ECG shows no abnormalities or ischemic changes. Two subsequent troponin measurements are within normal limits. Which of the following is most likely seen in this patient on further evaluation?

choices.text: Simultaneous contractions of the lower esophagus on manometry
Contrast-filled pouch in the esophagus on barium swallow
Distal esophageal stenosis on barium swallow test
ST-segment depression on cardiac stress test

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with dysphagia accompanied by chest pain. The fact that the symptoms occur only while eating, but not every time, favors the diagnosis of diffuse esophageal spasms (DES).  

DES (also known as distal esophageal spasm) is a medical condition characterized by uncoordinated esophageal contractions that presents as dysphagia, regurgitation and chest pain. The pain often mimics myocardial ischemia but without relation to exertions. There is no particular relationship to food, but it can be triggered by cold fluids. Barium study may show a “corkscrew”’ pattern at the time of the spasm. On manometry, high intensity, disorganized contractions are typically seen. The pathogenesis is thought to be related to impaired inhibitory innervation, which leads to premature and rapid contractions of the distal esophagus secondary to altered synthesis and/or degradation of endogenous nitric oxide.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Irregular mass on endoscopy  :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with esophageal cancer, which typically presents with progressively worsening dysphagia (dysphagia to solids initially, followed by liquids later in the course) accompanied by weight loss. The most common types are squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma. This patient has no significant risk factors (e.g., smoking, alcohol), and the dysphagia does not occur with every meal.   
✅ Simultaneous contractions of the lower esophagus on manometry:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Contrast-filled pouch in the esophagus on barium swallow:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a Zenker diverticulum, a medical condition caused by an outpouching of the esophageal wall through a weakness in the area of the muscular wall of the hypopharynx known as the Killian triangle. Patients typically present with halitosis, dysphagia, and regurgitation of undigested food. Occasionally, the appearance of a mass in the neck can be observed.   
❌ Distal esophageal stenosis on barium swallow test:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with achalasia, a motility disorder of the esophagus caused by degeneration on the inhibitory neurons in the esophageal wall. Patients typically present with an insidious onset of dysphagia to both solids and liquids as well as regurgitation of undigested food. Although this patient’s symptoms can be explained by achalasia, the dysphagia doesn’t occur with every meal, which makes achalasia less likely.   
❌ Low ferritin on iron studies:
Incorrect: Iron deficiency anemia is the mechanism behind Plummer-Vinson Syndrome, which presents with a classic triad of dysphagia, iron deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs. Other symptoms may include glossitis, angular cheilitis, koilonychia, splenomegaly, and symptoms of iron deficiency anemia (e.g. fatigue). Plummer-Vinson Syndrome is typically seen in women in their 4th to 7th decade of life. The absence of other symptoms (e.g., fatigue, glossitis) makes this diagnosis less likely.   
❌ ST-segment depression on cardiac stress test  :
Incorrect: ST-segment depression on cardiac stress test is suggestive of ischemia due to obstructive coronary artery disease (CAD). Although this patient’s symptoms can be partially explained by ischemia, the symptoms only occur at meal time, which makes ischemia less likely.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to difficulty swallowing and retrosternal pain. For the past 2 days, she has had pain with swallowing which has progressively worsened to the point of avoiding all food and drinks. She has not had similar symptoms in the past. Medical history is significant for coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, seasonal allergies, and osteoarthritis. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 30 years. Medications include aspirin, metoprolol, loratadine, lovastatin, and piroxicam as needed. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. The oral mucosa is clear without erythema or exudate. Cardiac auscultation reveals no murmurs, and ECG shows normal sinus rhythm without ischemic changes. The rest of the physical examination is normal. Endoscopy is obtained and shows multiple round ulcers in the proximal esophagus with relatively normal surrounding tissue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with acute onset of dysphagia, no prior history of GERD, and multiple round ulcers seen in the proximal esophagus on endoscopy. In light of the use of multiple NSAIDs medications (i.e., aspirin and piroxicam), the most likely diagnosis is pill-induced esophagitis.  

Certain types of medications are associated with esophagitis due to direct damage to the mucosa by different mechanisms. These include tetracyclines, bisphosphonates, ferrous sulfate (local acid burn),  potassium chloride (local hyperosmolality), and aspirin and NSAIDs (disruption of the cytoprotective barrier).  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Viral esophagitis:
Incorrect: Herpes simplex virus infection of the esophagus can present with similar symptoms and does present with round ulcers within the esophagus. However, most patients are immunocompromised.  
❌ Gastroesophageal reflux disease  :
Incorrect: Patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) typically present with heartburn and regurgitation. Heartburn is most commonly experienced postprandially, with certain types of food or when lying down. The ulcerations seen in peptic esophagitis instead tend to be irregular or linear, multiple, and are located in the distal esophagus.   
❌ Candida esophagitis:
Incorrect: Oropharyngeal candidiasis can be seen in patients with antibiotic use, infants, older adults with dentures, chemotherapy or radiation therapy to the head and neck, as well as immunodeficient patients (e.g. HIV). Most patients with oropharyngeal candidiasis are asymptomatic or may describe a “cottony” feeling in the mouth, along with loss of taste and concomitant pain. Endoscopy will likely show thrush rather than ulcers. None of these features are seen in this patient.   
✅ Pill-induced esophagitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Eosinophilic esophagitis:
Incorrect: Eosinophilic esophagitis is a chronic, allergic, inflammatory disorder of the esophagus with a strong association with atopic conditions (e.g. seasonal allergies). Typical presentation includes dysphagia, food impaction, and refractory heartburn. However, endoscopy typically shows stacked circular rings, proximal strictures, linear furrows, and whitish papules.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with a several month history of burning epigastric pain approximately 3 hours after eating. The patient reports he is often woken up at night with abdominal discomfort and nausea. He does not have any previous medical problems and does not take any medications. The patient undergoes endoscopy, which demonstrates the following pathologic lesion.  


Retrieved from: Wikipedia   

Which of the following is the most likely complication of this disease process?

choices.text: Gastric outlet obstruction due to scarring
Diffuse lesion with raised margins and distant metastasis

questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette presents with chronic abdominal pain and an endoscopy that demonstrates an ulcer in the duodenum of the small intestine. If left untreated, duodenal ulcers can progress to scarring, fibrous deposition and ultimately gastric outlet obstruction.  

Duodenal ulcers are the most common type of ulcer and are almost exclusively due to infection with H. pylori. Associated clinical features often include weight gain, as well as pain relieved with eating. Other rare causes of the disease include a gastrin-producing tumor referred to as Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Duodenal ulcers are caused by decrease in the mucosal barrier leads to increased permeability to gastric acid secretion or increased gastric acid secretion.  

In contrast to duodenal ulcers, gastric ulcers have a tendency to have worsening pain with eating, are associated with weight loss, and are associated with an increased risk of gastric cancer. All gastric ulcers must undergo biopsy, whereas duodenal ulcers are only biopsied if they have characteristic malignant features.  



Option Analysis

✅ Gastric outlet obstruction due to scarring:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diffuse lesion with raised margins and distant metastasis :
Incorrect: Gastric cancer is uncommon with duodenal ulcers. For this reason most duodenal ulcers do not require biopsy unless the lesion has features concerning for malignancy.   
❌ Postprandial pain:
Incorrect: Postprandial pain is a complication that occurs due to gastric ulcers. Based on the image, this ulcer is located in the duodenum, which is associated with relief of pain after eating.    
❌ Weight loss :
Incorrect: Weight loss is a complication associated with gastric ulcers; however, weight gain is associated with duodenal ulcers.   
❌ Grossly thickened stomach wall:
Incorrect: Linitis plastica is the characteristic term for diffuse gastric cancer, which appears as signet ring cells on histologic examination. Duodenal ulcers do not predispose to the formation of diffuse gastric cancer.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the office due to difficulty swallowing for the past 2 months. The patient describes intermittent difficulty swallowing solids which improves with water or by chewing her food more. She also reports feeling more tired during this time period. Medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals pale conjunctiva. Which of the following may be seen on further evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has Plummer-Vinson Syndrome, which presents with a classic triad of iron deficiency anemia (e.g., fatigue, tachycardia, pale conjunctiva), esophageal webs, and dysphagia. Among the answers options above, only koilonychia (spoon nails) is associated with iron deficiency.  

An esophageal web is a thin, mucosal, noncircumferential membrane that grows within the esophageal lumen and may cause dysphagia. It is usually located in the proximal esophagus. Diagnosis is made by endoscopy and/or barium swallow test. An esophageal web can be seen as part of Plummer-Vinson Syndrome or as a separate entity.  

Plummer-Vinson Syndrome is a rare disorder caused by chronic iron deficiency. It is typically seen in white women between 40-70 years old, but it has also been described in children and adolescents. Other signs and symptoms include glossitis, angular cheilitis, koilonychia (as seen in this patient), splenomegaly, enlarged thyroid, and symptoms of iron deficiency anemia (e.g. fatigue). Diagnosis of Plummer-Vinson syndrome is important due to the increased risk for developing esophageal squamous cell carcinoma. Treatment consists of iron repletion, which often leads to rapid resolution of the dysphagia. However, in patients with significant dysphagia, esophageal dilation may also be required.  

Option Analysis

✅ Koilonychia :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Scaly skin:
Incorrect: Scaly skin is associated with vitamin A deficiency. Other signs and symptoms of vitamin A deficiency include corneal degeneration, immunosuppression and night blindness.   
❌ Swollen gums:
Incorrect: Swollen gums are associated with vitamin C deficiency. Other signs and symptoms of vitamin C deficiency include easy bruising, petechiae, “corkscrew” hair, hemarthrosis, anemia, poor wound healing, perifollicular and subperiosteal hemorrhages, and weakened immune response.  
❌ Delayed wound healing:
Incorrect: Delayed wound healing is associated with zinc and vitamin C deficiency. Other signs and symptoms of zinc deficiency include suppressed immunity, male hypogonadism, reduced adult hair (axillary, facial, pubic), dysgeusia (taste abnormality), and anosmia.   
❌ Subacute combined degeneration:
Incorrect: Subacute combined degeneration is associated with vitamin B12 deficiency. Other signs and symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency include megaloblastic anemia and paresthesias.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the clinic due to the recent onset of throat pain, fever, and substernal burning pain. Medical history is notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia and end-stage renal disease, for which he received an allograft renal transplantation from a deceased donor 6 months ago. Medications include azathioprine and TMP-SMX. Temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Examination of the oropharynx is normal without exudate or erythema. The abdomen is soft with mild epigastric tenderness. Leukocyte count is 5000/mm3. An endoscopy is obtained and reveals multiple shallow linear ulcers in the distal esophagus. Which of the following best characterizes the organism responsible for this patient’s findings?
questions.solution:
The constellation of an immunocompromised state, fever, odynophagia, dysphagia and linear ulcers found on endoscopy is most consistent with cytomegalovirus (CMV) esophagitis. CMV belongs to the herpes virus family, all of which are enveloped double-stranded DNA viruses.   

CMV is a common pathogen that mainly affects immunocompromised patients, including solid organ transplant recipients, HIV patients, hematopoietic cell transplant recipients, and patients treated with immunomodulating therapy. Transmission can occur through close contact carriers, sexual exposure, or blood and tissue exposures. CMV is capable of diverse clinical manifestations including hepatitis, febrile syndromes, pneumonitis, retinitis, encephalitis, esophagitis, and colitis. CMV esophagitis is characterized by linear shallow ulcers on endoscopy. Microscopic examination shows intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions (“owl eye”). Available treatments include ganciclovir, valganciclovir, and foscarnet.  

Other common causes of esophagitis in an immunocompromised patient are depicted in the table below:  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Non-enveloped double-stranded DNA virus:
Incorrect: Examples of non-enveloped double-stranded DNA viruses include adenovirus and papillomavirus; however, neither of these is associated with esophagitis.   
❌ Non-enveloped single stranded RNA virus:
Incorrect: An example of a non-enveloped single-stranded RNA virus include the Picornaviruses family (i.e., poliovirus, echovirus, rhinovirus, coxsackievirus, and hepatitis A); however, none of these causes esophagitis.   
✅ Enveloped double-stranded DNA virus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Enveloped single-stranded RNA virus:
Incorrect: An example of an enveloped single-stranded RNA virus includes influenza virus. Although some of the patient’s symptoms can be explained by influenza infection, it is not a cause of esophagitis.   
❌ Dimorphic fungi :
Incorrect: An example of dimorphic fungi includes Candida albicans, which can cause esophagitis in immunocompromised individuals. However, candida esophagitis is typically not painful and white plaques are typically seen, not linear ulcers.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2 month history of chest pain and cough. The patient reports he frequently wakes up coughing with a substernal burning sensation.  He has no significant past medical history but reports a 20-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is  37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 14/min and blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg. Physical examination shows faint end-expiratory wheezing bilaterally on chest auscultation. Initial troponin level is normal, and an ECG reveals normal sinus rhythm. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the medication used to treat this patient's condition?

choices.text: Inhibition of the parietal cell H+/K+ ATP pump
Beta-2 agonist of bronchial smooth muscle cells
Stimulates angiogenesis and the formation of granulation tissue
Na+ channel blockade and inhibition of depolarization
Dilatation of large coronary arteries and arterioles

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a several month history of burning chest discomfort, cough, and wheezing with a normal ECG and troponin level consistent with a diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Appropriate treatment for GERD includes lifestyle modification and medications that reduce acid suppression, such as proton pump inhibitors (PPIs). GERD is caused by transient lower esophageal sphincter relaxation, which results in the reflux of stomach contents into the esophagus.  

Clinically, GERD presents with burning in the throat or chest, regurgitation, or an acidic taste in the mouth while lying flat or lying flat immediately after eating. GERD can also present with atypical features including chronic cough, globus sensation (the feeling that something is stuck in the throat), wheezing, or nausea. Risk factors for GERD include obesity, hiatal hernias, and pregnancy, since these conditions tend to increase intrathoracic pressure and regurgitation of stomach contents. Smoking is also a notable risk factor, due to its ability to relax the lower esophageal sphincter.  

If left untreated, GERD can progress to esophageal stricture, Barrett esophagus and ultimately esophageal cancer. Untreated GERD can also result in chronic laryngitis, asthmatic exacerbations, and wheezing due to reflux of stomach contents into the large airways.    

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibition of the parietal cell H+/K+ ATP pump:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Beta-2 agonist of bronchial smooth muscle cells:
Incorrect: Beta agonist therapy with albuterol is the primary treatment for patients with asthma. The wheezing in this patient is secondary to GERD, as stomach contents reflux into the airway causing bronchospasm.   
❌ Stimulates angiogenesis and the formation of granulation tissue:
Incorrect: This answer describes the mechanism of sucralfate, a medication often used in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease. Sucralfate can be used to treat GERD; however, given its short duration of effect, it is used for acute symptomatic relief as opposed to long-term therapy.  
❌ Na+ channel blockade and inhibition of depolarization:
Incorrect: Like sucralfate, viscous lidocaine can help provide symptomatic relief to patients with acute exacerbations of GERD, but it does not provide long-term symptomatic relief.   
❌ Dilatation of large coronary arteries and arterioles:
Incorrect: Nitrates are commonly used to treat anginal type chest pain. Coronary artery disease and GERD can often be difficult to distinguish clinically. The patient in this vignette does not have a history of diaphoresis or an exertional component to reproducing the chest pain. In addition, the ECG and troponin levels are normal, making acute coronary syndrome unlikely.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to frequent chest pain over the last three weeks. The pain is retrosternal and described as a “burning sensation.” It is more prominent when she lies down after dinner. Past medical history was notable for hiatal hernia and non-ST elevation myocardial infarction a year ago. Her medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, metoprolol, and lisinopril. She does not smoke or use illicit substances. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable except for mild epigastric tenderness. Electrocardiograms obtained during rest and while exercising are unremarkable. Troponin levels are within normal limits. A decision is made to start the patient on omeprazole. Which of the following steps involved in acid formation in the stomach is directly inhibited by this agent?

choices.text: Secretion of histamine from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells
Formation of hydrogen ion and bicarbonate
Release of acetylcholine from neuronal endplate
Release of hydrogen ions from parietal cells

questions.solution:
This patient has retrosternal, burning chest pain that is more prominent when she lies down after dinner. She most likely has gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and is started on omeprazole, a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) that is considered a first-line agent for treating GERD.  

Physiologically, when food enters the stomach, it causes the stomach walls to distend. These changes lead to the activation of branches of the vagus nerve and the release of acetylcholine, thereby activating M3 receptors on parietal cells of the stomach. Next, the G-cells in the gastric antrum release gastrin, activating CCK2 receptors on parietal cells. Gastrin and acetylcholine activate the enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells, which release histamine and cause activation of H2 receptors on gastric parietal cells. Activation of M3, CCK2, and H2 receptors increases the conversion of water and CO2 to H+ and HCO3- by carbonic anhydrase. The H+ is then pumped out of the parietal cells and the stomach via the H+/K+ ATPase pump. These H+ ions combine with Cl- ions to form hydrochloric acid and help decrease the stomach pH.   

PPIs work by irreversibly inhibiting the H+/K+ ATPase pump, thereby inhibiting the release of hydrogen ions into the stomach. The result is decreased acid production.  



Option Analysis

❌ Secretion of gastrin from G-cells:
Incorrect: Gastrin is the major hormonal regulator of gastric acid secretion. The pH of the stomach influences gastrin release. Fasting and increased gastric acid in the stomach inhibit its release via somatostatin secretion from delta cells. Omeprazole and other proton pump inhibitors do not directly affect gastrin secretion.  
❌ Secretion of histamine from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells:
Incorrect: Histamine is the major paracrine stimulator of acid secretion. Its secretion is upregulated by gastrin and acetylcholine. Proton pump inhibitors, such as omeprazole, do not directly affect histamine release.  
❌ Formation of hydrogen ion and bicarbonate:
Incorrect: Carbonic anhydrase assists in forming hydrogen and bicarbonate ions from CO2 and water. Although carbonic anhydrase is found in the stomach's parietal cells, its activity is not affected by proton pump inhibitors such as omeprazole.  
❌ Release of acetylcholine from neuronal endplate:
Incorrect: Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) that decreases the release of hydrogen ions into the gastric lumen. PPIs do not directly affect acetylcholine release from the neuronal endplate.  
✅ Release of hydrogen ions from parietal cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the office for a routine visit. Over the past three months, he has experienced an acid-like taste in his mouth that worsens when recumbent. In addition, he has had nightly coughing episodes. The symptoms have been minimally responsive to over-the-counter antacids. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, for which he takes hydrochlorothiazide. His BMI is 32 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for dental erosions but is otherwise unremarkable. The patient is started on cimetidine. Compared to other medications of its class, which of the following side effects is unique to cimetidine?
questions.solution:
This patient, with a 3-months history of reflux symptoms (acid taste in mouth and nocturnal cough) and dental erosions, most likely has gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Cimetidine is a H2-receptor antagonist (H2RA) that can improve symptoms of GERD.    

There are several H2RAs available, including cimetidine, ranitidine, famotidine, and nizatidine. This class of medication works by inhibiting acid secretion via blocking H2 receptors on gastric parietal cells. Side effects, though uncommon, include vitamin B12 deficiency, mental status changes, cardiotoxicity, and idiosyncratic myelosuppression. Moreover, gynecomastia and impotence occur using cimetidine in a dose- and time-dependent fashion that usually resolves once the medication is discontinued. This effect is relatively specific for cimetidine and rarely happens if treatment is limited to standard doses for eight weeks or less.  

Option Analysis

❌ Vitamin B12 deficiency:
Incorrect: Vitamin B12 deficiency has been associated with the long-term use of all H2-receptor antagonists. This side effect is not unique to cimetidine.  
❌ Mental status changes:
Incorrect: Mental status changes (e.g., confusion, somnolence, dizziness, hallucinations) have been associated with the use of H2-receptor antagonists. These changes appear to be more common in elderly patients with renal or hepatic dysfunction who require intensive care. This side effect is rarely seen in outpatient settings. Moreover, they are not exclusive to only cimetidine.  
❌ Prolongation of QT interval:
Incorrect: Cardiotoxicity (e.g., prolongation of QT interval, sinus bradycardia, hypotension, atrioventricular block) has sometimes been observed in patients taking any of the H2-receptor antagonists. The risk is greater with rapid intravenous infusion, high doses, conditions that delay drug clearance (e.g., renal or hepatic dysfunction), and underlying cardiac disease.  
✅ Gynecomastia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Clostridium difficile colitis:
Incorrect: Proton pump inhibitors (e.g. omeprazole), not H2-receptor antagonists, have been associated with an increased risk of C. difficile infection.
